newsitem.title: IRAQ: U.N. envoy calls Iraq oil deal a moderate succeess.
newsitem.headline: U.N. envoy calls Iraq oil deal a moderate succeess.

text.p: A senior U.N. official in Iraq said on Saturday the country's oil-for-food deal with the U.N. had been "moderately successful" so far.
U.N. humanitarian coordinator Staffan de Mistura told reporters he did not expect food and medical supplies under the second phase of the deal to reach Iraq before December.
"I will describe phase one of the oil-for-food deal as moderately successful," said de Mistura, an Italian.
He was speaking at the end of his tour of duty in Iraq, where he is being replaced by Denis Halliday of Ireland.

The oil-for-food deal, which allows Iraq to sell $2 billion worth of oil over six months, took effect last December and was renewed for another six months on June 8. Iraq resumed oil exports for the second phase on Wednesday, having delayed these while modifying plans for aid distribution.
De Mistura said the deal had brought to Iraq just 1.3 million tonnes of food and medicine, short of the 2.3 million tonnes envisaged under the first phase.
"Why moderate success? Because it should have brought two million tonnes (of food and medicine) instead of only 1.3 (million tonnes)," he said.
U.N. resolution 986 governing the plan was "complex" and the process of winning approval for contracts from the U.N. sanctions committee on Iraq had delayed arrival of relief supplies.
De Mistura said the Baghdad government had started signing contracts to buy food worth $906 million and medicine and other humanitarian needs worth $414 under the second phase of the deal.
Iraq has frequently complained about the committee, accusing the United States and Britain of being behind decisions to delay or forbid contracts.
Last Tuesday, Iraq accused the U.S. of blocking 142 contracts, among them an Iraqi plan to buy 100 ambulances from France.
"The only comment I can make is that the ambulances are needed," de Mistura said.
He said delays in the provision of medical supplies arose because pharmaceutical companies began production of the consignments only after approval of the contracts.
De Mistura expected the first shipment of relief goods under the second phase would be in December and arrival of shipments under the first six months would continue until November.
